title: 114_hr5123
content: The Act is titled the "Honoring Emergency Response Officers Benefits Reform Act of 2016" or the "HERO Benefits Reform Act of 2016." It includes a presumption that officers acted properly and addresses the backlog of claims. The "HERO Benefits Reform Act of 2016" includes a presumption of officer's proper actions and addresses the backlog of claims by amending the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968. In appeals of Bureau determinations to deny claims, the reviewing official or court must conduct a de novo review. An individual can file a subsequent claim with the Court of Federal Claims for benefits under this part without final agency action on the original claim. If the Bureau does not make a determination on the original claim within 1 year, or denies the claim and the appeal is not resolved within 180 days, the individual can file a subsequent claim with the Court of Federal Claims for benefits. The individual can appeal a denial of their claim to a hearing officer and then to the Director if the original claim is denied within 180 days. The Court of Federal Claims will review the claim without considering any prior determinations by the Bureau or its hearing officers. The United States Court of Federal Claims will determine the date of the original claim filed with the Bureau, regardless of whether the Bureau has deemed the application incomplete. SEC. 4. TRANSPARENCY. Amends Subpart 1 of part L of title I of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 by adding a new section titled "SEC. 1207. ANNUAL REPORT." The Bureau must submit an annual report to Congress and publicly publish it on their website within 60 days after each fiscal year. The report should include the number of claims filed, granted, and denied during the year, categorized by type of benefit sought and public safety officer. It should also list the claims filed as of the end of the fiscal year, along with the filing dates. The Attorney General must publicly release a report on the date and reason for pending claims that the Bureau has been unable to decide on. SEC. 5. Extending death benefits to fire police and fire investigators. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to extend death benefits to fire police officers and fire investigators who are officially recognized members of public safety agencies. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to extend death benefits to fire police officers and fire investigators who are officially recognized members of public safety agencies. The amendment defines a fire investigator as an individual authorized to conduct fire and explosion investigations in accordance with state or local law. The Uniting and Strengthening America by Providing Appropriate Tools Required to Intercept and Obstruct Terrorism Act of 2001 is amended to update specific sections.
